docs.lead_paragraph: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE GREAT AMERICAN WAISTLINE. Putting It on and Taking It Off. By Chris Chase. 367 pages. Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $14.95. ONCE upon a time, fat was sexy and prosperous, and thin was a stage of starvation. As Chris Chase observes in the introduction to ''The Great American Waistline,'' there was a time when Lillian Russell, at 200 pounds, was referred to as ''airy, fairy Lillian, the American Beauty,'' and her frequent dinner companion, Diamond Jim Brady, whom one restaurateur called ''the best 25 customers we have,'' was looked up to as a figure of substance in every sense of the phrase. Now things are just the other way. Thin is what you get in the pages of Vogue, and fat is the cleaning lady.
